awd_titl_txt: Conference: Two-Year College Data Science Initiative (TYCDSI) Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by engaging two-year college faculty in a workshop aimed at developing new data science associate degree pathways. By fostering collaboration and knowledge exchange, this project seeks to create a robust community of practice that will connect faculty working on such programs with one another and provide them with essential knowledge and skills needed to evolve this field of study. This endeavor will expand programming for students to pursue exciting new career paths in an emerging field. This initiative aligns seamlessly with the mission to advance the frontiers of knowledge, strengthen the Nation's scientific infrastructure, and cultivate a diverse, skilled workforce.

The Two-Year College Data Science Initiative project will support a workshop for two-year college faculty working to develop data science programs at their institutions.  Workshop topics include forming interdisciplinary teams, examining exemplary data science curricula, establishing partnerships with baccalaureate institutions, researching regional workforce needs, and program evaluation. After the workshop, participants will continue to connect as a community of practice (CoP) within the American Mathematical Association of Two-Year Colleges (AMATYC). Participants will develop skills and confidence needed to create data science transfer programs at their institution, including a plan for program development, initiating articulation agreements with partner institutions, and plans for program development and evaluation. The NSF IUSE: Innovation in Two-Year College STEM Education (ITYC) Program seeks to accelerate the impact of and advance knowledge about emerging and evidence-based practices in undergraduate STEM education at two-year colleges. 

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: American Mathematical Association of Two-Year College

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: American Mathematical Association of Two-Year College

por.por_cntn:
1. Cover Page

  • Two-Year College Data Science Initiative (TYCDSI)

  • Kathryn Kozak - PI

  • Ambika Silva - Co-PI

  • Vinodh Chellamuthu - Co-PI

  • Rebecca Wong -Co-PI

  • Jennifer Travis  - leadership team member

  • American Mathematical Association of Two-Year Colleges (AMATYC)

  • Grant Number : NSF DUE 2402290

  • Conference Name: Two-Year College Data Science Initiative (TYCDSI) Workshop

  • Conference Dates and Location: College of the Canyons, Santa Clariita, CA, June 21 to 22, 2024

  • Date of Report: January 28, 2025

2. Executive Summary

June 21 through 22, 2023, 53 participants, organizers, and presenters came together at the College of the Canyons in California, for a workshop on creating a data science program at a community college. The participants were from community colleges throughout the US. The presenters were from community colleges and universities. 

3. Introduction

  • Conference Overview: The workshop provided knowledge for the participants to create data science pathways at their colleges.

  • Goals and Objectives: 

    • Outcome 1: Develop skills and confidence needed to create a data science transfer.

    • program at their institution, including a plan and timeline for program development.

    • Outcome 2: Develop a strategy for initiating articulation discussions with local

    • universities.

    • Outcome 3: Develop a plan for engaging in ongoing program evaluation.

    • Outcome 4: Develop a community of practice to support ongoing program development.

4. Conference Activities

  • Participation: The workshop had 44 participants from community colleges, four organizers, and five presenters from both community colleges and universities were brought together. 

  • Presentations: The following were presentations were given at the workshop:

    • why data science programs at two-year colleges are important

    • Guidance on developing a data science program, including curriculum mapping, forming advisory boards, facilitating articulation agreements, and evaluating the program's effectiveness. 

Collaborations: None. 

5. Outcomes and Impact

  • Knowledge Gained: There are many colleges that are either creating or refining their data science program. There is a community of practice where programs can be shared with each other. 

  • Impact on Research: A survey was conducted of participants to assess the workshop. Of the 44 participants, 32 participated in the survey. 90.6 percent of the participants evaluated the effectiveness of the workshop highly effective while 9.4% evaluated it as effective. If there is another workshop the presentations and work time need to be more mixed to reduce information overload. 

  • Dissemination: There is a community of practice on myAMATYC called Statistics and Data Science ANet. There are posts in that community to see how people are progressing. Emails are sent out to participants to see where they are in the process. There was also a request for more professional development to help create programs and also to learn the technology they need to learn to teach the topics. 

6. Financial Report

  • Budget Summary: Most of the funds were in support of participants. Each of the 24 participants that was funded by the grant had their hotel paid, up to $550 for travel to the workshop, and food during specific activities of the workshop were all paid by the workshop. There was no registration fee for the workshop and the College of the Canyons provided the facilities and one of the meals. A small amount of funds were used to pay the local arrangements person for the work she did arranging the college facilities and the hotel space. The travel funds, food, and hotel were also paid for the organizers and presenters. All participants were provided with a webscription to AMATYC that gives them access to the myAMATYC community. 

7. Challenges and Lessons Learned

  • Challenges: Of the 57 people who applied for the workshop, only 24 participants could be funded to attend., So of the 44 people who attended the workshop, 20 of them found their own funding. This means that 7 people who wanted to attend were not able. The other challenge was having enough time to present all the material and have time for people to work on their program. 

  • Lessons Learned: The idea of having all the information presented on the first day, and leaving time on the second day for people to work created information overload. If there is a future grant, spacing out the material over multiple days would be better. 

8. Conclusion

The workshop was well received, since 100% of the participants who completed the survey rated their time spent at the workshop as valuable. Eighty-four percent of the respondents felt that they had learned new ideas that they can use to start a data science program. Seventy-eight percent rated the presentations very high. There is a community of practice that has been created on myAMATYC. Overall, the workshop was a success and the hope is to have a larger workshop in the future to include more two-year colleges in the development of a data science program and to provide professional development for how to teach the data science material.



Last Modified: 01/30/2025
Modified by: Kathryn Kozak
